data.title: Carol Balinski: Christopher Derby named executive director of the Jesuit Center for Spiritual Growth

data.text:
For information on submitting an obituary, please contact Reading Eagle by phone at 610-371-5018, or email at obituaries@readingeagle.com or fax at 610-371-5193.

Most obituaries published in the Reading Eagle are submitted through funeral homes and cremation services, but we will accept submissions from families. Obituaries can be emailed to obituaries@readingeagle.com.

In addition to the text of the obituary, any photographs that you wish to include can be attached to this email. Please put the text of the obituary in a Word document, a Google document or in the body of the email. The Reading Eagle also requires a way to verify the death, so please include either the phone number of the funeral home or cremation service that is in charge of the deceased's care or a photo of his/her death certificate. We also request that your full name, phone number and address are all included in this email.

All payments by families must be made with a credit card. We will send a proof of the completed obituary before we require payment. The obituary cannot run, however, until we receive payment in full.

Obituaries can be submitted for any future date, but they must be received no later than 3:00 p.m. the day prior to its running for it to be published.

Please call the obituary desk, at 610-371-5018, for information on pricing.

In a quiet transition on Jan. 1, Christopher Derby became the first executive director of the Jesuit Center for Spiritual Growth in Lower Heidelberg Township.

Derby had previously served as interim executive director for a year.

“It’s a statement of affirmation on the part of the board (of the Jesuit Center) that what I’ve done is effective and the right direction,” Derby said about his new title in a telephone interview this week.

Derby, 54, is not a priest but a religious brother, a member of the Society of Jesus, an order of the Roman Catholic Church.

He explained that in 2016 the Jesuit Center for Spiritual Growth became separately incorporated from the other occupant of the Lower Heidelberg Township property, the Jesuit Community of the Novitiate of St. Isaac Jogues. Some of the resident Jesuits are retired, while others work in the community or are staff members of the Jesuit Center.

“Generally we are in a bit of a transition,” Derby said, noting the religious residential community has gotten smaller as its members have aged.

Susan Bowers Baker formerly was the director of spirituality programs at the Jesuit Center and she continues to work part time on Derby’s staff.

One of Derby’s goals in his newly created position is to dispel rumors about the future of the Jesuit Center, which he said is not threatened.

The center continues to offer programs, religious retreats and activities for students of all ages as well as those in other denominations.

“We are also trying to encourage a connection between spirituality and the arts,” Derby said.

He has established an art room, hoping to bring in more visual artists and musicians to develop retreat programming.

Musical programming, in particular, appeals to Derby, who is a vocalist with the Ignatian Schola, a musical ensemble including Jesuits and colleagues, rooted in Ignatian spirituality. It performs at Jesuit spirituality-related events on the East Coast. Derby said he continues to perform infrequently with the musical group, which is based mostly in New York.

Derby, a native of Long Island, N.Y., still has family members there as well as an aunt in Lancaster County.

He earned his bachelor of arts degree in religion at Kenyon College and holds master’s degrees in English from Fordham University and theological studies from Boston College.

Derby worked in middle and secondary education at Nativity Mission Center and Xavier High School in New York City as well as in Buffalo, N.Y.

He also served for five years as director of vocations for the New York and Maryland Provinces of the Society of Jesus.

Derby’s first encounter with the Jesuit Center was when he was a Jesuit novice and made a 30-day retreat there. He returned many times as a retreatant.

He noted the property covers 240 acres, mostly wooded, with some farmland that is rented out. There is also a cemetery on the property for the Jesuit community as well as a labyrinth, groves and religious statues. In short, it’s a perfect place for a spiritual retreat.

“I find that people here turn a corner and find a new piece of art or a vista,” he said.

An upcoming directed retreat from Jan. 26-28 is already sold out. Derby said directed retreats are largely silent, although participants do meet one on one with a spiritual director.

“In many cases, they (participants) are working on their relationship with God as they have come to know God,” Derby explained.

Another retreat, from March 16-18, is geared to those who are personal or professional caregivers to others. There are still openings for that event, which also will feature music by the local music group Opus One.

“It will be a good opportunity for those who do a lot of caring to get some TLC in return,” Derby observed.

Other upcoming programs:

Feb 14: Two sessions of a four-hour Lenten program, “Lent: A Season of Grace,” led by Linda Robinson.

April 2-6: Jody Cole will return to lead her popular icon writing retreat.

May 11-13: A Mother’s Day retreat featuring a speaker who is a spiritual writer as well as a mother and a grandmother.

To register for a program or for more information, go to jesuitcenter.org.

Contact Carol Balinski: 610-371-5007 or cbalinski@readingeagle.com.

Originally Published: January 13, 2018 at 12:00 a.m.
